title: 110_s666
content:
The "Oil Industry Tax Break Repeal Act of 2007" repeals oil industry tax breaks, including a change from 5-year to 7-year amortization of geological and geophysical expenditures for major integrated oil companies. It also imposes a limitation on percentage depletion. SEC. 102 amends the Internal Revenue Code to limit the depletion allowance for oil or gas wells. The amendment applies to taxable years after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 103 terminates the treatment of natural gas distribution lines as 15-year property. SEC. 104 terminates temporary expensing for equipment used in refining of liquid fuels. The effective date applies to property placed in service after the enactment of the Oil Industry Tax Break Repeal Act of 2007, with exceptions for properties under binding contracts before February 16, 2007. SEC. 105. Natural gas gathering lines treated as 15-year property. Effective date applies to property placed in service after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 105. Natural gas gathering lines treated as 15-year property. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to classify natural gas gathering lines as 15-year property for tax purposes if the original use begins after the enactment of this clause. SEC. 106. TERMINATION OF DEDUCTION FOR INTANGIBLE DRILLING AND DEVELOPMENT COSTS. Amendment to the Internal Revenue Code to terminate the deduction for intangible drilling and development costs. Effective date applies to property placed in service after the enactment of the Act, with exceptions for properties under binding contracts or started construction before February 16, 2007. SEC. 106 terminates the deduction for intangible drilling and development costs for taxable years after the enactment date. SEC. 107 terminates the enhanced oil recovery credit. SEC. 107 terminates the enhanced oil recovery credit for taxable years after the enactment date. SEC. 108 terminates the credit for producing oil and gas from marginal wells. SEC. 109 amends the tax code to end the treatment of Alaska natural gas pipelines as 7-year property. It applies to property placed in service after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 110 denies deductions for large integrated oil companies for income from domestic production of oil, natural gas, or primary products. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 denies deductions for large integrated oil companies for income from the sale, exchange, or other disposition of oil, natural gas, or any primary product thereof. The term 'primary product' is defined in a similar manner as in a previously repealed section. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 defines a large integrated oil company as one with gross receipts exceeding $1,000,000,000 and an average daily worldwide production of at least 500,000 barrels of crude oil. These amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2007. SEC. 111. REVALUATION OF LIFO INVENTORIES OF LARGE INTEGRATED OIL COMPANIES. SEC. 111. REVALUATION OF LIFO INVENTORIES OF LARGE INTEGRATED OIL COMPANIES. The taxpayer, if an applicable integrated oil company for its last taxable year ending in 2006, must increase the value of historic LIFO inventories of petroleum products and decrease cost of goods sold accordingly. If increases exceed cost of goods sold, gross income is adjusted. The term "layer adjustment amount" is defined for this purpose. The term "layer adjustment amount" refers to a calculation involving the number of barrels of crude oil represented by a historic LIFO layer. It is not considered a change in accounting method and does not result in additions to tax for underpayments of estimated tax. The term "barrel-of-oil equivalent" is defined as per section 29(d)(5) before its redesignation by the Energy Tax Incentives Act of 2005. No addition to tax under section 6655 for underpayment related to taxable year described in subsection (a) if created or increased by this section. An "applicable integrated oil company" is defined as having specific production and gross receipts criteria for the taxable year ending in 2006. For the taxable year ending in 2006, all persons considered a single employer under certain sections of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 are treated as one entity. MODIFICATIONS OF FOREIGN TAX CREDIT RULES APPLICABLE TO LARGE INTEGRATED OIL COMPANIES WHO ARE DUAL CAPACITY TAXPAYERS. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to include special rules for large integrated oil companies that are dual capacity taxpayers. Any amount paid to a foreign country or possession of the United States by such companies will not be considered a tax under certain conditions. The Internal Revenue Code includes special rules for large integrated oil companies that are dual capacity taxpayers. Any excess amount paid to a foreign country or possession by such taxpayers will not be considered a tax, as long as it exceeds the generally applicable income tax imposed by that country or possession. The term 'dual capacity taxpayer' refers to individuals subject to this subsection. The term 'dual capacity taxpayer' refers to individuals subject to a levy of a foreign country or possession, who receive a specific economic benefit from that country or possession. A 'generally applicable income tax' is an income tax imposed by a foreign country or possession on income derived from conducting a trade or business within that country or possession. The term 'large integrated oil company' is defined as an integrated oil company with gross receipts exceeding $1,000,000,000 and an average daily worldwide production of at least 500,000 barrels of crude oil. The amendments made by this section apply to taxes paid or accrued in taxable years beginning after the enactment of the Act, except where contrary to any treaty obligation of the United States. TITLE II--ENERGY TRUST FUND

SEC. 201. DEDICATION OF RESULTING REVENUES TO THE ENERGY TRUST FUND. Subchapter A of chapter 98 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by adding a new section: "SEC. 9511. ENERGY TRUST FUND." The Energy Trust Fund is established in the Treasury of the United States to accelerate the use of clean domestic renewable energy resources, promote energy-efficient products and practices, and increase research and development. Amounts equivalent to revenues from the Oil Industry Tax Break Repeal Act of 2007 are appropriated to the Fund for these purposes. The Energy Trust Fund aims to boost clean renewable energy research, development, and deployment. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for the subchapter. The Energy Trust Fund is established to support clean renewable energy initiatives. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for the subchapter.
